intro: Cymbosema, commonly known as the marsh hibiscus, is a genus of flowering plants belonging to the Malvaceae family. It is characterized by its herbaceous or semi-woody stems and alternate leaves that are usually ovate to lanceolate in shape. The flowers are typically showy, with five petals and a prominent central column, often in shades of pink, red, or white. Cymbosema species are often found in wetland or marshy environments, thriving in moist, nutrient-rich soils. They play an important role in their ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various insects and birds.
